english_translation: Narrated by Mujahid: In the verse 'as if there were deafness in both his ears' - he means heaviness (of hearing)

chainIssues: Unknown narrator at beginning of chain

potential_issues.issue: Muhammad ibn al-Husayn (first narrator) is Majhul al-Hal - no clear documentation of his reliability
potential_issues.impact: This significantly weakens the beginning of the chain. Unknown narrators at the start reduce overall reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Ibrahim ibn Fahd (second narrator) is also Majhul al-Hal with insufficient documentation
potential_issues.impact: Another unknown narrator in early part of chain compounds the reliability issue.

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Abi Najih uses 'an (indirect transmission) rather than direct hearing term
potential_issues.impact: While Ibn Abi Najih is Saduq, the indirect transmission term introduces minor ambiguity in the connection.

potential_issues.issue: This is a maqtu' hadith (statement of tafsir interpretation, not from Prophet)
potential_issues.impact: As an athar/interpretation, this is at the level of scholar commentary rather than prophetic tradition.

english_translation: Narrated by Mujahid: In the verse 'Indeed, Allah possesses knowledge of the Hour' - he said: A bedouin man came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ and said: My wife is pregnant, inform me what will she deliver? Our land is barren and dry, inform me when rain will fall? I know where I was born, inform me where I shall die? So Allah revealed this verse. Mujahid said: These are the keys of the unseen which none knows except Him
